Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Combined Proxy and Model Investigation of Late Holocene Paleoclimate in the Horn of Africa
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to investigate the mechanisms causing drought events in the Horn of Africa over the last 4,500 years using a combination of proxy measurements and modeling. Researchers from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute and Columbia University's Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory will collaborate to generate the first known paleoclimate record for the region. The project will use proxy data from a sediment core collected in the Gulf of Aden to determine regional sea surface temperatures (Mg/Ca, TEX86) and hydroclimate (carbon and hydrogen isotopes from plant leaf waxes) at a resolution of ~20 years. The regional sea surface temperature data will be used to drive Community Earth System Model (CESM) simulations of key drought and pluvial events. Model output will be compared with the proxy hydroclimate record to assess the Horn of Africa's sensitivity to regional SSTs versus more remote (global) climate drivers.

Drought history in the Horn of Africa is closely tied to political instability, making its population particularly vulnerable to climate change. The investigators will engage policy makers focused on this issue through a workshop held in collaboration with the Woodrow Wilson Center?s Environmental Change and Security Program. The project will support three early-career researchers, two of which are female with no prior NSF support, as well as training of an undergraduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Horn of Africa is a region challenged by famine, piracy, and political instability. Climate change in this region acts as a "threat multiplier", i.e., it can exacerbate existing political, social, and economic situations. Understanding climate change in this region is key to developing future projections of conflict and trade in the Indian Ocean rim. 

The goal of this NSF project was to understand past climate change in the Horn of Africa with an eye towards implications for the future. Before this project, very little was known about how rainfall in the Horn region responded to climatic forcings like greenhouse gases, global temperatures, and, on longer geological timescales, the slow changes in the Earth's orbit. We remedied that situation by reconstructing Horn of Africa climate change from marine sediment cores collected from the Gulf of Aden, spanning a variety of time intervals from the last 1000 years to the last 200,000 years. We used chemical signatures in these cores - specifically, the isotopic composition of plant leaf wax compounds, which are transported to the ocean from land - to track changes in aridity on land. This technique works well because the isotopic signature changes strongly depending on whether the climate is wet or dry.

As a result of our research, we now know far more about climate change in this key region. For example, we found that during the last few thousand years, there was a close link between global temperatures and aridity in the Horn - dry conditions were always associated with warm times. Given this relationship, we expect that future warming will be associated with widespread drying in the region - i.e. more severe drought and famine. This is an important finding because global climate models predict the opposite (they suggest wet conditions in the region). Regional climate models match our paleoclimate-based predictions better, suggesting that we need to rely on these to get accurate forecasts of how African drought will behave in the future.

Further back in geological time, we found that climate in the Horn of Africa has experienced rapid and severe shifts between wet and dry states, in phase with large-scale changes in the African monsoon system. One of the most dramatic changes took place 60,000 years ago, when the climate suddenly shifted from a "green phase" (high rainfall and ample vegetation) to a dry phase that was even drier than today (below 8 inches of rainfall per year). Incidentally, this was the time when our early human ancestors first migrated out-of-Africa to fully colonize Eurasia. The coincidence suggests that climate could have been a motivating force for migration for our ancestors, much as it is today. 

The results of our Horn of Africa research have been published in top scientific journals (Nature, Science) and have practical applications for future predictions of climate in the Horn of Africa. The project also supported young researchers for five years, including undergraduate students, technicians, and an early-career female scientist. Finally, the results of these studies have been featured in a number of public lectures given by the lead scientist designed to foster appreciation for the interaction between climate, drought, and human behavior.
